claim:
Frequently stated reasons for the exclusion of publications were that cohorts failed to meet the eligibility criteria and did not report the data of interest.Sub-cohorts
For the public sub-cohorts and for Commercial Germany, citation by systematic reviews ranged between 52 and 63% and was higher than in Commercial International with 38% (Fig. 5 and Table 4).
title: Fig. 5.
caption: Proportion of trials cited by systematic reviews

claim:
Both, the type of intervention and the number of primary outcomes are not associated with the inclusion probability, whereas larger trials are significantly more often included in reviews than smaller trials (Additional file 9).Trials included in clinical guidelines
Cohort
We found 574 citations of 178 trials (26%) in guidelines (Fig. 6).
title: Fig. 6.
caption: Proportion of trials cited by guidelines, shown by type of publication

claim:
Larger trials are about twice as often included in guidelines than smaller trials (Additional file 10).Overall impact
Lifecycle of trials
Figure 8 shows the fate of the trials included in our cohort from registration to publication and to their impact on clinical practice.
title: Fig. 8.
caption: Impact on clinical practice. Total number of trials, published articles and systematic reviews (SRs) and guidelines, citing the published articles

claim:
Nevertheless, in our cohort, a relevant percentage did not find an inclusion in clinical practice: only 309 (45%) of the trials were included in systematic reviews and 178 (26%) in guidelines.Cohort
Of all trials, 274 (40%) generated no impact: 115 (17%) of the trials were not published and of the published trials, 160 (23%) were not cited by either a systematic review or a guideline (Fig. 9).
title: Fig. 9.
caption: Publication and impact of trials

claim: The distribution of the three “impact-proportions” concerning inclusion in reviews and/or guidelines showed only minor differences between the sub-cohorts (Fig. 10).
title: Fig. 10.
caption: Impact of trials per sub-cohort

claim: The high proportion of guidelines in psychiatry and psychotherapy, cardiovascular disease and neurology is related to a high proportion of publications and systematic reviews for these fields (Fig. 11).
